full_history.content: Show me Section 101 of the Virginia Building Code.

As a building code consultant specializing in the Virginia Building Code, I've reviewed Section 101, which covers essential administrative provisions.  Understanding this section is crucial for correctly applying the entire code.  It lays the groundwork for how the code is structured, referenced, and ultimately enforced.

Here's a breakdown of the key components of Section 101, synthesized from several resources:

* **General Provisions (101):**  Section 101 addresses the general administrative rules of the Virginia Building Code. This section sets the stage for understanding and applying the rest of the code.  It provides critical context for all subsequent chapters.

* **Short Title (101.1):** The code can be referred to as either the "Virginia Existing Building Code" or the "VEBC".  It's part of the larger "Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, Part II, Existing Buildings." For new construction,  it's the "Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, Part I, Construction," cited as the "Virginia Construction Code" or "VCC."  Remember the distinction between VEBC (existing buildings) and VCC (new construction).

* **Incorporation by Reference (101.2):**  This is a critical point. Section 101.2 lists the specific editions of model codes and standards referenced within the Virginia Building Code. Pay close attention to this section in both the VEBC *and* the VCC as it specifies crucial supporting documents, such as the International Existing Building Code (IEBC) for existing buildings and the International Building Code (IBC) for new construction.  Note that the researched context mentions referencing Section 101.2 of the VCC for a complete list, even when discussing the VEBC, highlighting the interconnected nature of these documents.

* **Order of Precedence (101.6):**  This clarifies the hierarchy within the code.  Chapter 1 of both the VEBC and VCC takes precedence over conflicting provisions in subsequent chapters of their respective referenced International Codes (IEBC and IBC).  This ensures that Virginia-specific modifications and amendments override the general model code language.

* **Use of Terminology (101.5):** When you see "this code" or "the code" in Chapter 1 or the referenced International Codes, it refers to the Virginia Building Code (either VEBC or VCC, depending on the context).  This clarifies potential ambiguity and reinforces the Virginia amendments' authority.  Note that within a referenced *standard* (as opposed to the code itself), "this code" refers to that specific standard unless otherwise stated.

* **Administrative Provisions (101.7):**  This section will outline the administrative procedures, including permitting, inspections, and enforcement, specific to Virginia.  While not detailed in the provided research, it's a crucial part of Section 101 and dictates how the code is implemented in practice.

Your next step is to identify whether you are working with an existing building (VEBC) or new construction (VCC).  Then, carefully review the referenced codes and standards listed in Section 101.2 of the appropriate document (VCC for a comprehensive list). This will ensure you're working with the correct and most up-to-date requirements for your project.  Pay close attention to any Virginia-specific amendments that might supersede the model code language. Finally, familiarize yourself with the administrative procedures outlined in Section 101.7 to understand the practical application and enforcement of the code.
